profile.name: Alex
profile.history: The patient has a history of substance abuse and has been through rehab to overcome it. He has had issues with his family, particularly with his mother, where he has felt rejected and emotionally neglected. He has struggled with obesity since childhood, which has affected his self-esteem and body image. He also has a history of being victimized and bullied due to his weight.
profile.intermediate_belief:
Helpless: I'm just not very good at handling stress and I have poor self-control, which is why I need to not put myself in stressful situations. 
 Unlovable: If I show my true self, people will reject me the way my mother rejected me.
profile.intermediate_belief_depression:
Helpless: There's nothing I can do to change my situation. I cannot control myself. 
Unlovable: I don't deserve to be happy, so why even try to stay clean?
profile.coping_strategies: The patient has adopted avoidance as a coping strategy by distancing himself from his family to reduce exposure to negativity and conflict. He has started scheduling pleasant activities and planning his day ahead of time in order to maintain a sense of control over his emotions and circumstances.
profile.situation: Alex's cousin invited him to attend his upcoming wedding.
profile.auto_thought: It will be stressful and negative; people will ask me questions I cannot answer or don't want to answer; my mum would be ashamed of me and critical of me as always; They don't want me there anyway, nobody likes me in this family.
profile.behavior: Ignored the invitation and did not respond to the RSVP request. Ignored phone calls from family.

messages.content: Hello, what's on your mind today?

Well, I got an invitation to my fathers's wedding, but I'm feeling really anxious about it. I haven't responded yet, and I guess I'm just avoiding the whole thing. I don't know, the thought of being around family and all those people is just... overwhelming.

It sounds like the idea of being at your fathers's wedding is causing you a lot of anxiety, especially with the thought of being around many people. That can be really overwhelming and stressful. When you think about attending the wedding, what specific thoughts or worries come to mind?

Honestly, I'm worried about feeling out of place and awkward. Like, everyone will be looking at me and maybe judging me, especially with how things are with my family. I just dread feeling rejected or ignored, like how my mom makes me feel sometimes.

It sounds like you're concerned about feeling judged or rejected, which is understandably distressing. This seems connected to past experiences with your family, especially with your mom, which might contribute to these feelings. What evidence do you have that people will react in that way, and is there an alternative way you might view this situation?

I guess a lot of it stems from how things have been with my mom. She's never really accepted me, so I just assume others won't either. It's hard to see it differently, but maybe not everyone will be like that. It's just tough to shake off these feelings.

It makes sense that your experiences with your mom would influence how you expect others to perceive you. It's understandable that these feelings are hard to shake off, but acknowledging that not everyone might react the same way is a good start. What might be some signs or experiences that could help you see that others may accept you differently?

I guess, sometimes when I hang out with friends, they seem to enjoy my company and don't judge me. Maybe if I remind myself of those times, it could help. But it's hard to feel that way when the family is involved, you know? It's like I'm expecting the worst.

It's great that you have positive experiences with friends who appreciate and accept you, which can be reassuring. Family dynamics can indeed be more challenging, and it makes sense that you might expect the worst based on past experiences. How might you use these positive interactions with friends to build confidence and manage your expectations with family events like the wedding?

I suppose I could try to focus on the fact that not everyone at the wedding will be like my mom. Maybe I can lean on the support of any friends who are there or even just remind myself of the good times with them. It's just a matter of reminding myself that I'm not alone and that I have people who care about me.

That sounds like a helpful approach, focusing on the positive relationships you have and using them as support. Reminding yourself that you're not alone and that there are people who care about you can be very empowering. As we wrap up, what's one small step you can take to prepare for the wedding with these thoughts in mind?

I guess I could start by actually responding to the invitation, maybe just to test the waters. It feels like a small step, but at least it's something. And maybe, if I decide to go, I can plan to meet up with or stay close to people I trust during the event.

That sounds like a thoughtful and manageable plan, responding to the invitation and staying close to people you trust can provide comfort. Taking these steps can help you feel more in control of the situation. How do you feel about these plans and taking this approach?
Honestly, I feel a bit more hopeful about it. It's not easy, but having a plan makes it seem less daunting. I still have my doubts, but maybe it's worth trying to see how it goes.

It's great to hear that having a plan gives you a sense of hope and makes the situation feel more manageable. Doubts are natural, but taking these steps shows your willingness to try something different and see how it unfolds. As we wrap up, what will you do to remind yourself of this hopeful outlook when doubts arise?

I think I'll try to remind myself of the positive moments I've had with friends and the support I have from them. Maybe I can write down a few affirmations or positive reminders to look at when I'm feeling doubtful. Just something to keep me grounded and focused on the good.

That sounds like a wonderful idea, using affirmations and reminders of positive moments to stay grounded. It's a proactive way to maintain focus on the support and good experiences you have. As we conclude our session, what are some affirmations or reminders you'd like to start with?

I think something like, "I am worthy of love and acceptance," and "I have people who care about me." Also, maybe, "I can handle this," to remind myself that I am capable. These feel like good starting points to keep me centered and positive.

Those affirmations are powerful and can be a great source of reassurance and strength. It's wonderful that you've identified these positive reminders to help you stay centered and confident. As we conclude, how do you feel about using these affirmations moving forward?
I feel cautiously optimistic. It feels a bit strange to rely on affirmations, but I can see how they might help change my mindset. I'm willing to give it a try and see if it makes a difference.
